name: Integers s = (p1+p2)/4 such that p1 and p2 are consecutive primes and s can be written in the form p*2^k with k>=0 and p>2 prime.
link: Karl-Heinz Hofmann, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
example: For n = 2: a(n) = 6 because 4 * 6 = 24 and 24 is the sum of the two consecutive primes 11 and 13 and the factorization of 6 is 3 * 2^1.
mathematica: Select[Plus @@@ Partition[Prime[Range[400]], 2, 1]/4, IntegerQ[#] && PrimeQ[#/2^IntegerExponent[#, 2]] &] (* _Amiram Eldar_, Apr 21 2025 *)
program: from sympy import isprime, sieve as prime
(PARI) is(n) = my(v=valuation(n, 2), n2);if(!isprime(n>>v), return(0)); n2 = 2*n; n2 - precprime(n2) == nextprime(n2) - n2 \\ _David A. Corneth_, Apr 21 2025
author: _Karl-Heinz Hofmann_ and _Hugo Pfoertner_, Apr 18 2025
